content:
I am a PhD student and Graduate Teaching Assistant at University of Illinois at Chicago, advised by Drs. Joel Brown and Boris Igić. My research is is primarily focused on the evolution and ecology of plant breeding systems in large angiosperm families.
My other activities include helping Chicagoland high school students with their math homework, discussing the moral complexities of Deep Space 9, and transmitting from KD9LSF.
summary: I am a PhD student and Graduate Teaching Assistant at University of Illinois at Chicago, advised by Drs. Joel Brown and Boris Igić. My research is is primarily focused on the evolution and ecology of plant breeding systems in large angiosperm families.
title: Lucy E Delaney

summary: The stunning variety of forms displayed by angiosperms has fascinated biologists for centuries. Both the reproductive organs and the mechanisms by which reproduction ensues are more diverse in this group of organisms than any other. Because sexual systems determine the patterns and distribution of genetic variation, they have important macroevolutionary and ecological consequences. Despite this, there remains a surprising paucity of data regarding their distribution in some of the largest plant families, limiting the potential to answer questions about how and why these systems evolve and inform expectations for future study.
title: Breeding Systems in the Legumes
